NEW YORK AREA
INAUGURATION OF HELICOPTER SERVICE
NEW JERSEY-NEW YORK METROPOLITAN AREA-OCTOBER 15, 1952

THE PORT OF NEW YORK AUTHORITY
in Sighth Menue-at isth Street Newlfork 11 SNU
AVIATION DEPARTMENT
Fred M. Hass
October 15, 1952
To Friends of the Port of New York Authoriro:
This letter was carried on the first regularly scheduled helicopter air mail tight in
the New ersev-New York Port District.
This flight from La Guardia Airport to New York International Airport to Newark
Airport on October 12, 1992 macks the first step in the establishment ot regular air mail,
freight, and passenger transportation by helicopter in this area. The Port of New York Authority
wishes to take this opportunity to congratulate New York Airways, Inc.. on the establishment
or he nicopter air mai service ac this time and to exoress once more our tirm belter in the future
the heliconer as a method of shortchau transpotation.
For the next few months, New York Airways will operate regular helicopter air mail
flights on a triangular route serving La Guardia, Newark, and New York Internacional Airports.
When additional equipment becomes available, the company will extend this service co
suburban points which it has been authorzed to serve by the civil acronautics Board.
Eventually, helicopter service wIll also carry cargo and passengers on these routes and on
shutcle routes connectine Manhattan with the airports.
We are convinced that the helicopter can contribute greatly to the solution ot the
serious traffic problems in large metropolitan areas. Its ability to overcome surtace obstacles
and to land or take off in small places enables it to create an entirely new level ot vehicular
ints. We are proud on the occasion of this tirst tight to welcome New York Airways to
the tamily of carriers serving the world's greatest regional airport system.
Please accepe the First Flight Air Mail Cachet in which this message is enclosed
as our memento to vou on this occasion.
Herbert O. Fisher

Fisher, Chief, Aviation Development Division; "This letter was carried on the first regularly scheduled helicopter air mail flight in the New Jersey-New York Port District"
